Walpole and his kind clung to these ideals of the brave and honorable knight precisely because such men had vanished from the world, if they had ever truly existed at all. The gothic past became a dream of something better, a time when men knew honor and duty and did not shy from either. Walpole wrote in dark times, when politics had grown foul and accusations flew like carrion birds. Perhaps he thought that something fundamental had been lost, some essential goodness that had once lived in men's hearts but had withered and died in the modern world. We see this most clearly in Frederic, a character who carries the weight of chivalric virtue like a crown of thorns. He comes to us first in description, a prince who has known suffering, who has walked away from tragedy, who men believe fell fighting the infidel. The gallant and courteous Knight exists in these pages as something larger than life, excessive in his virtue as all things in Gothic tales must be excessive.

Supply chain it moves like a river through the land of commerce. Raw materials to finished goods flowing ever onward to the waiting hands of customers who know not from whence it came. In 1982 a man called Oliver gave name to this thing that had existed nameless since the first trader walked the first road with the first goods. He called it supply chain management and in doing so he captured the essence of planning and control and implementation that feeds the hunger of want.

Six pillars hold up this temple of commerce. Production. Supply. Inventory. Location. Transportation. Information. Like ancient gods they stand watch over the flow of goods, and the men who tend to business bow before them seeking favor in the marketplace.

Production stands first among these, a cornerstone laid deep in the bedrock of enterprise. It asks the questions that must be answered. When. Why. Where. How. The managers peer into the great void of the marketplace like seers reading entrails, seeking signs of what the people want. The market speaks in whispers of demand and they must listen close to hear its truth. Then they must decide what will be born into the world and in what numbers and from which wombs of industry it will come forth.

I knew this truth when I worked the floors of Walmart and Target both. There was a scripture for everything. How to dress. How to move. How to receive the great trucks that came like metal beasts in the night bearing their cargo. Everything written down in books like industrial bibles telling all who would read them the proper way of things.

Supply comes next in the procession. It speaks of capabilities and partnerships and the breaking of whole things into parts. Managers must look upon their domains and know which pieces fit where like some great industrial puzzle. Sometimes they must reach out beyond their walls to other makers and other doers, seeking that thing called velocity. Velocity that promises quality and flexibility while keeping the coin in the purse, though few who seek it truly find it.

They were books of another time. Victorian they called them. All manner and detail laid out like bones in the desert sun, bleached white with aristocratic concern and societal affairs that meant nothing to the dead or dying. But there were others. Different ones. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights stood apart like dark sentinels in the gathering dusk, their pages filled with a mystery that crawled beneath the skin like fever dreams. They bore witness to things that proper society dared not speak of.

In one such passage the boy Oliver walks through a fevered haze. He walks with killers. With Sikes and Crackit who argue in voices that echo through his skull like gunshots in an empty church. The words come and go like wind through dead grass. Then the real shots ring out and the night explodes in fire and screaming and lights that dance like devil-moths against his eyes. Some force, nameless and terrible, drags him through the chaos while pain gnaws at him like a starved dog that won't let go.

These fever dreams run through both books like dark water through underground caves. In Oliver's tale they show what lies beneath, the rot and the fear and the helplessness of a child caught in the machinery of fate. When the shooting comes back to him in the twenty-eighth chapter it comes like a visitation, like something holy and terrible both. The boy relives it all while his body searches for salvation it dont believe in. He's powerless. Always was. The pain aint even a surprise no more, just a companion walking beside him in the dark. The question aint about who shot him. The question is about whose will brought the boy to this place, because it sure wasnt his own. Old Fagin had worked his poison deep, wearing down the boy's spirit like water wearing down stone until there wasnt nothing left but acceptance of the dark.

Time itself becomes a stranger. Day passes into night or maybe there never was a day at all. Just darkness bleeding into darkness while silence stretches out like a rope with no end.

Years back I worked with the young ones after their schooling was done for the day. Small faces bent over books and papers in the late afternoon light. Most I could help well enough but reading and words were what I knew best. There was this boy called Adrian, might have been eight or nine, who couldn't read worth a damn. Something wasnt right with how he saw the letters. Some he knew like old friends and others may as well have been hieroglyphs scratched in ancient stone. His English was pure as mountain water but his blood was Mexican sure enough. We fought those letters like they were demons until the day his mother came.

She walked in while I was minding the stragglers left behind from some excursion. Not a word of English passed her lips, just rapid-fire Spanish like soft bullets. My own Spanish was poor and broken but we made do with gestures and half-understood words. That's when the truth hit me like a hammer blow. Adrian could read just fine. It was our strange English letters that were foreign to him, not the words themselves. Whether that knowledge ever served him I cannot say.

I tell this tale because it speaks to something deeper, something that runs through the veins of our schools here in California like a dark current. The wall between languages aint always what you'd expect. Even a child who speaks English pure as springwater might stumble when the letters dance strange on the page. We all know this devil exists but the killing of it aint so simple. For Adrian the medicine was clear enough - teach him our letters, teach him our sounds. But for them that barely speak English the cure aint so clean. No single answer exists in this world or the next. Dual language learning, throwing them in the deep end, private teaching, special English classes - none of these alone will slay the beast. The truth lies in using them all like weapons in an arsenal.

The dual language way of teaching aint just for the Spanish speakers but for all our young ones. Studies show these children rise above their peers like hawks over field mice. Some folk fear it's wasteful, that most children won't gain nothing from it. That's a lie black as pitch. If we made this the way instead of the exception, every child would grow stronger for it. But how to do it? Force every teacher to speak two tongues? No, that's a fool's errand. But having them that can speak both languages helping in the classroom, that's no dream but a real possibility hard as iron.

From youth we are told of something greater than ourselves. Something vast and unknowable that stretches beyond the boundaries of what mind can hold. They shepherd the young ones to wooden buildings with crosses hung like dead things on the walls or to temples where old men in robes speak ancient words. Some take what their mothers and fathers gave them and hold it close like a blanket against the dark while others cast it away saying there aint nothing out there but what we know and what we see. And we take up these beliefs like weapons only to lay them down again for different ones when the first ones fail us. Each soul walking its own path through the spiritual dark searching for some light to lead it home.

The old man said cardinal and nothing more. We set there on the porch listening to the rain hammer the tin roof while smoke from our cigarettes rose up in pale wisps to join the clouds. Water poured from the gutters and drowned the flowers that grew there, petals beaten flat against the mud. He looked out into the gray distance with eyes that seemed to see both now and then at once. His clothes hung on him like a scarecrow's and his head showed pale through thinning hair. He wouldnt look at me. I knew I could not speak of what was coming for speaking makes real what we wish was not. I moved closer and hugged him and we sat there watching the June rain fall in the growing dark.

He died in December. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The doctors with their medicines and machines had kept him breathing past their predictions but what good was breath when it only meant more pain. What sort of god would craft such torment. In the nighttime I spoke no prayers for if there was a god he had turned his face from me long ago.

I would not watch him die. Could not. The life that gave me life deserved better than my witness to its ending. I knew him better than they did. Better than the blood kin that gathered round his bed. He would not want his child to watch death take him. So I lay curled in my bed for three days waiting for word.

None came.

He walked the fields of Caroline county and knew the soil like his own blood. John Taylor. Man of the earth and of words both. The land spoke to him in ways that politics never could though he served in that capacity too and the marriage of these things made him what he was. A voice crying out against the wilderness of government overreach. Against the darkness that men brought forth when they strayed from honest work.

The republic stood newborn on the continent like some vast experiment in human nature. No ancient ghosts to bind it. No old world chains to wear. Taylor saw in this emptiness a terrible possibility. The chance to build something true. He knew that rights given by God or nature or whatever power ruled the hearts of men were like bones in a skeleton. Break one and the whole thing goes wrong. Goes twisted. These things must stay beyond the reach of any government that would call itself just.

In the raw state of nature the strong preyed upon the weak and the clever preyed upon both but Taylor believed civilization must rise above such base instincts. Must find a way to account for the light and dark that dwelled in every human heart. Good and evil. No middle ground between them. He wrote that government carried all the virtues and vices of the men who wielded it, like a sword that could heal or harm depending on whose hand held the hilt.

The principles he called good were simple things. Protection of what a man owned. The enhancement of agriculture. The restraint of those who would profit from paper and promises rather than honest work. Self-interest drove all men, he knew, but like fire it could warm a home or burn it down. Government must contain this force, must channel it, must be watched always lest it turn from servant to master.

He stood with others who read the Constitution like scripture, demanding every word be weighed and measured. The federal government must be bound tight, he said, kept small, kept lean, kept honest. A bloated government would turn tyrant as surely as meat turns rotten in summer heat. But words alone were not enough. The spirit of the law must be known, must be held sacred. The Declaration that came before was truer still, he thought. It spoke of sovereign states, not one nation. Separate fires burning bright against the dark.

He stood and looked down and the looking was a thing without meaning or purpose save that it was done. The mind worked at it like some machine spinning in emptiness, taking in what lay before it and letting go again without holding to any truth or knowing. Thoughts came and went like smoke in a wind. No thought stayed.

He'd bought him a book once. Some woman artist had told him of it. About drawing and the mind and how these things worked together or didnt work together and how a man might learn to see what was before him truly and not just what his mind told him ought to be there. The book spoke of frames. How putting a frame around a thing made it something else entirely. How a kitchen full of things became just a bowl of fruit on a table if you framed it right.

Standing there he couldnt frame nothing. The sight was too big for frames. Like them painters of old had their colors. Blues and greens and all the colors of God's earth. If he was to paint this scene it would be brown. Nothing but brown.

His fingers found the handle. Touched it. The muscles worked beneath the skin like creatures with their own purpose. Water moved in its ancient circles. Clear as light itself. Things broke apart in it and vanished. He worked the handle again. Faster now. Urgent. The brown mass stayed fixed like something alive and willful. Like it had made up its mind to stay.

He stood there in his tie that choked at his throat. Green like poison. Feet planted like a man about to receive news of death. The mop loose in his grip like a broken standard. Some previous visitor had left this offering. This message to them that cleaned the drugstore toilets. He flushed again and again and watched the water move and settle and move again. Then his hand went to the paper. Wrapping and wrapping until the hand was white as bone. He bent at the waist like a man in prayer. The hand went down into the water like something seeking baptism in darkness...

They die on the roads these children. Die in twisted metal and shattered glass while the night wraps around them like a shroud. The government men in their white coats say the young brain aint ready for such things but they dont need to tell what any fool can see with his own eyes. Inexperience sits heavy in their bones and death rides shotgun in their fathers pickup trucks.

The children gather like crows. Two then three then four in a car and the metal beast beneath them growls with promise and threat both. Studies done in California show what we already know in our hearts - that death multiplies with each young soul added to the cabin. Some states try to hold back the tide with their paper laws and provisional permits but its like trying to dam a river with chicken wire.

Zuckerman the headshrinker says eighteen years aint enough. Says the young ones seek the thrill of speed like junkies seek the needle and they cant help themselves no more than a rattler can help its poison. The boomers babies are coming he says. Coming like a flood to wash our roads in blood and metal and grief.

The answer lies simple as a coffin nail. Keep them from the wheel till eighteen years have worked their tempering. Let them learn in classrooms and parking lots with teachers watching careful as priests. Make it the same in every state so there aint no place for death to slip through the cracks. Six hours behind the wheel and fifty with a grown soul watching. Numbers writ in law like commandments.

This aint new thinking. But then neither is death and we seem to keep finding ways to deal in that particular trade.

They called it CAPD and it was a thing that lived in the brain and made the sounds wrong. Not in the hearing but in the knowing of what was heard. Like a radio playing through broken glass. The brain took the sounds and twisted them and made them strange and foreign though the ears worked just fine.

The disorder first showed itself in the middle years of the last century. Italian men with clinical minds sought to understand it. They worked in sterile rooms with machines and wires and children who could not parse the world of sound around them. Kimura came later with his tests of competing sounds fed into separate ears like twin serpents of noise coiling into the skull.

The affliction manifested in ways various and cruel. Some could not tell where sounds came from in the void of space as if they walked in darkness eternal. Others could not separate one sound from another or know when words meant their opposite through the tone of voice that carried them. The sounds came like waves breaking upon rocks, each one washing away the memory of the last until nothing remained but confusion.

To diagnose it they brought forth an arsenal of tests and observations like ancient priests seeking auguries in the behavior of their subjects. Audiologists and speech pathologists and psychologists all brought their tools to bear, watching and measuring and recording. They fed sounds into ears and measured the echoes that returned. But no single test could catch this ghost in the machine of the mind, and none could say from whence it came. It remained elusive as smoke, real as rain, present as pain.

They would sit children in rooms and bombard them with sounds, asking them to pluck meaning from chaos. Numbers and words would rain down like hail, and they would watch as the children struggled to catch them, to hold them, to make sense of the storm. Some could and some could not and in this way they separated the afflicted from the whole.

They'd asked what I aimed to do and I told them plain. Work with the children. The broken ones. The ones cast off and forgotten like old shoes in a ditch. Them that's been touched by darkness that walks in daylight wearing the skin of kin. Values aint just words wrote down in some book. They're carved deep in the bone. Service. Respect. The old ways of right and wrong that dont bend nor break.

I'd wandered some years not knowing my path. Watched folks run from their demons or drown em in whatever poison they could find. Got myself some learning in the ways of the mind at Piedmont College in 09 but still the path weren't clear. Then come a summer day I'll not forget. Boy of sixteen set on my friend's couch like a sparrow ready to fly. Eyes darting. Hands working at nothing. Running from them that should've protected him but didn't.

Next day I drove out to where he come from. Talked to the law standing in that yard where evil had made its home. Told em what I knew from my schooling. They asked me to speak to the parents and I did. Watched em squirm and lie, calling their boy's cry for help manipulation. Simple disputes, they said. Nothing simple about it. That's when I knew what I had to do.

Justice aint just a word neither. Society talks about the worth of one soul while trying to make every soul look the same. I never did hold with that. Through them school years I made my stand. Wore my colors like war paint. Put metal in my flesh where I pleased. Stood with them that society said weren't worth standing with. Fought the old poisons of hate and fear wherever they showed their face. Some folks say protest aint proper. I say there aint nothing more proper than standing against what's wrong.

That's the truth of it. Plain as I can tell it.

The night comes and with it the darkness that some cannot escape into sleep. There are those who walk among us bearing the curse of wakefulness, their minds racing like wild horses across the vast plains of consciousness while others find peace in the void. They call it insomnia but names mean little to those who suffer its relentless grip.

The men of science speak of two paths to understanding this affliction. One path leads through blood and bone, through the twisted helixes of our making that we inherit from those who came before. The other winds through the territories of man's own making - the streets and alleys of culture, the borderlands of race and wealth, the dark canyons between rich and poor.

In the laboratories they keep their mice in plastic boxes, watching as the creatures struggle between wake and sleep. The scientists speak of things called GABAB receptors, tiny gatekeepers in the hypothalamus that stand watch over the kingdom of sleep. They inject their potions - baclofen they call it - and observe as the mice surrender to unconsciousness. As if mice could tell us the secrets of human suffering.

They mapped these territories of sleep like ancient cartographers, drawing borders between what they call Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, primary disorders and secondary ones. Names upon names, categories within categories, as if naming a thing could capture its essence. Nightmare Disorder. Sleep Terror. Sleepwalking. Words that try to cage the uncageable.

In the end it all comes down to the firing of neurons in the dark meat of our brains, the dance of chemicals across synaptic gaps, the inheritance of cursed genes passed down like dark heirlooms through generations. And those who cannot sleep walk among us like ghosts, haunting fluorescent-lit offices and sterile classrooms, their eyes heavy with the weight of endless days.

Two and a half years I've walked these grounds. Four and a half seasons come and gone like wind across the valley. The campus stretches vast and merciless, a concrete expanse that swallows souls and time alike. In my first year they put me in East Halls, far out where the morning sun first touches university soil, beyond where most students dare venture save for football and spectacle.

The path from Stuart Hall to Willard was a pilgrimage. Twenty-five minutes through rain or snow or whatever god saw fit to cast down upon us. The old ones speak of times when East stood alone, islands of brick and mortar in seas of empty land. Now steel and glass rise where emptiness once dwelled. The Creamery. The healing house. Apartments like teeth in a giant's mouth surrounding it all. The campus grows like some living thing, consuming space, making distance longer with each passing season.

What salvation exists for those who must traverse these spaces? The bicycle stands alone. Simple machine. Two wheels and frame and chain. But it aint enough to have the machine. You need the riders and you need the paths that welcome them.

I knew a man who returned to the wheel after years away. Said he couldn't reckon why he ever stopped. Called it the only true way to move through this world. A bowl of morning grain can power you thirty miles or more, he said, and I reckon he spoke true.

I live off campus now, far as any dormitory, maybe farther. The bike was wisdom purchased cheap. Thomas building lies twenty-five minutes by foot from my door, but the wheels cut it to five if you're willing to push. Pollock Road runs straight as an arrow but aint always friendly to those who'd ride it. Walking has its merits but time is precious as blood in this place. Without the bike I'd lose thirty minutes, forty maybe, each day to walking. Two and a half hours every week vanished like morning mist. Add the other wanderings required of a student's life and time becomes a currency you cant afford to spend.

He saw the machines coming and knew their masters well. The World Controllers and their ilk. They had built their glass towers and concrete hives where men moved like insects, each to their own predetermined place in the great mechanism of society. The conditioning began at birth, perhaps before. No man could say. They called it community but it was a prison of the soul.

The people walked through their lives like sleepwalkers, pursuing pleasure with the mindless determination of addicts. They knew nothing of struggle or pain or the raw truth of existence. The Controller stood above them all like some dark god, dispensing soma and satisfaction in measured doses. Marx had seen it coming. The way the powerful would bend the minds of the weak until they could no longer recognize their own chains.

There was no love in this brave new world. No hatred neither. Just the endless cycle of consumption and shallow gratification. The men spoke of women like they spoke of machines, measuring their worth in pneumatic qualities and physical dimensions. The women traded stories of their couplings with the detached interest of cattle traders. Each class moved in its ordained circles, never questioning, never rising above their station. The Alphas and Betas, those who might have seen the truth of things, chose blindness instead. All except Bernard, who carried his doubt like a wound.

The lower orders - Deltas, Gammas, the rest - they were born to their servitude, their minds shaped before they drew first breath. Sleep-teaching had burned away any chance of rebellion or discontent. They consumed and labored and died, believing themselves blessed in their ignorance. The great machinery of capitalism ground on, feeding on their dreams, their desires, their very humanity. And above it all the Controller watched, counting his profits in the coin of human souls.

Four years past I sat in a classroom where they spoke of Islam, voices rising and falling like wind through desert scrub. The question hung there like smoke: was this faith born of violence. Now in these days the question burns hotter still, a flame that won't die down. Since the towers fell I watched how the papers and talking heads shifted from raw hatred to something else, something like submission. Strange days indeed when a man called Barack Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his veins, could reach for the highest office in this land.

The Prophet's tale gnaws at me. What they write of Muhammad stands against what history whispers in the dark corners of time. They say he was a peaceful man but I know different. Know how he rode with warriors across the sands, how tribes fell before him like wheat before the scythe, how the sword and the word went hand in hand. Yet in these pages they paint him gentle as a lamb, a martyr walking soft in the world until men saw truth in his eyes and followed. Followed like sheep to water.

And there in those pages they write of miracles. Mutton and milk multiplied like some dark echo of another story, older and truer. As if taking the bread and fish from Christ's own hands and putting them in another's. A theft of holy things. Making mockery of sacred blood.

They tell these tales second-hand, third-hand, passed down like old coins worn smooth with handling. Each teller adding his own truth until truth itself becomes suspect. Like smoke rising from a fire you cannot see.

What troubles me most is how they've made him soft, this warrior prophet. Made him meek and mild when history shows his sword arm was strong and his will was iron. I wonder if those who bow toward Mecca five times daily know the true face of the man they follow. Know the blood that stains the pages of their past.

The words of the Christ and what he knew in his time upon the earth were cast aside like chaff in the wind, scattered and forgotten in the wake of what men would later call Christian thought. Looking back across the wasteland of centuries we see only the long retreat from truth, each generation stepping further from the light into a darkness of their own making. Yet now in these latter days there comes a stirring, like wind across the desert floor, a wakening that cannot be stilled.

The old ones still cling to their beliefs like drowning men to driftwood, but their numbers grow thin and their voices fade. Among the faithful there rises a hunger for what was lost, a need to strip away the accretions of time like layers of dead skin until nothing remains but the raw truth of what the Nazarene brought forth from God. It may take generations, maybe centuries, but the wheel turns backward now and cannot be stopped.

This great undoing will sweep across the lands like wildfire, burning away the false doctrines that men have built, leaving only ash and truth behind. The church will endure, yes, but changed, transformed, stripped back to bone and sinew. Where once a thousand voices sang different songs there will be one voice, one truth, one way. Like rivers flowing backward to their source, all the scattered tribes of Christ will flow together again.

History shows us such reversals. Rome that once drank Christian blood became Christ's greatest temple. This land that once bound men in chains now sees those same men's sons in seats of power. And so it will be with the faith itself, unspooling like a thread pulled from an ancient tapestry, until we stand again at the beginning.

But mark this well: the key that unlocks this door lies in seeing the Christ's words not as dead letters carved in stone but as living water, flowing with meaning beyond mere words. To understand what came after, we must first look back to what came before.

In those ancient days there was only the faith of Abraham, the wellspring from which Christianity would flow. The one God, the holy books, the revealed truth - these were the foundations laid before Rome's eagles cast their shadow over Jerusalem in the year 63 before the Christ. But even then the people were divided, split like dry wood - Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and the common folk who knew little of such things.

The darkness that dwells in the heart of man aint nothing new and The Jungle shows it plain as day. Shows how the greed lives deep in the marrow of our bones and how we care nothing for them below us in the great chain of misery that binds us all. You can see it clear as death in them factory owners and managers, them lords of industry who built their empires on broken backs and spilled blood.

They built their kingdoms of steel and smoke, caring nothing for what lay crushed beneath. Sinclair wrote of how them buildings stood like black teeth against the sky, chimney stacks vomiting endless streams of smoke into the heavens, as if trying to poison God himself. The smoke rolled away toward the horizon like some great serpent, coiling and twisting until it disappeared where the earth meets the sky. The owners, they didnt care none for the poison they put into the air or the filth that ran from their slaughterhouses, rivers of blood and worse things that no man should have to name.

The workers was nothing more than meat to them. Disposable as the hogs they butchered. There wasnt no loyalty in that place, no decency neither. A man's worth was measured in pennies and dollars, his life cheaper than the copper in his pocket. They worked them men like mules and cast them aside just as quick, no warning, no mercy. Just the cold calculation of profit and loss written in ledgers stained with invisible blood.

Them that lived and died in Packingtown, they was caught in a web of their own making, though they didnt weave it themselves. No escape from the grinding machinery of industry that ate men whole and spit out bones. The unions that was supposed to help only fed off their misery like vultures on carrion. The foreign workers, them that came seeking the American dream, found instead an American nightmare. They hung there between life and death, survival dependent on the whims of men who was no better than the slave drivers of old. Their suffering was as certain as winter frost, their degradation as inevitable as darkness following light. And there aint no law of God or man that could save them from it.

They called it Dream-land and Poe knew it for what it was. He'd written it himself and called it among his better works though such things dont matter now and didnt matter then. The word Thulé appeared twice like dark sentinels at the edges of his verse, borrowed perhaps from Virgil who'd used it to name some distant shore beyond Britain where the Greeks reckoned the world fell away into darkness. But there was something else. Something closer.

The German writers had gotten into his blood. Among them was Goethe whose words Poe knew well enough that scholars like Karl J. Arndt would later trace the shadowed footprints between their works, seeing in Poe's lines an echo of the master's voice.

Goethe himself was dead by then. His Faust lay in two parts like a bifurcated serpent, the first coiled in 1808 and the second dying with him in 1832. Within those pages there was a tale of a king and his dead queen and a goblet that carried both memory and grief. The king drank deep and wept deeper until at last he walked to the edge of all things and cast the cup into the waters below. Then he closed his eyes and followed it into the dark. It wasnt hard to see Poe's own darkness there, his own cup of sorrow, his own dead love.

The word Thule appeared again in The Pit and the Pendulum but it was in Dream-Land where it found its true home, standing guard at beginning and end like black-robed sentries. The landscapes of both tales stretched out across the same wastes: colorless, empty, populated only by ghosts and memories that wouldnt die proper deaths but lingered like smoke in still air.

Poe knew Goethe's work as surely as he knew his own demons. He spoke of Tennyson's admiration for the German and in doing so revealed his own. The words had been there all along, waiting in translations and adaptations, seeping into the soil of American letters like blood into sand.

The law speaks of malice and rights and consequences but the truth of it is darker than any book of statutes. In the failing light of an October evening in California a manager sat eating his dinner while death or something like it waited patient in the aisles of his store. The spill lay there like some primordial ooze, transparent and lethal, the crushed remains of apples processed and jarred and shipped and spilled and now forming a slick that would alter the course of lives yet unknown.

They came to him twice. First Wayne and then Haddigan bearing news of the hazard but Martin would not be moved from his repast. He sat unmoved and uncaring like some petty god pronouncing judgment on the affairs of mortals beneath his notice. The store bore already the history of five who had fallen that year alone, their bodies caught in gravities cruel embrace, but such things did not trouble Martin's thoughts.

When Palmer fell it was as if ordained. Her back broke not with a sound but with a feeling, something ancien and terrible coursing through bone and sinew. The law speaks of conscious disregard and willful negligence but these are just words meant to cage the darkness in mens hearts. Martin knew what lay in wait in his domain. Knew it as sure as he knew the taste of the food he would not leave. Knew it as sure as he knew of those who had fallen before.

The question before the judge is one of punishment beyond mere compensation, of whether such calculated indifference rises to the level of malice that the law demands for special retribution. The evidence speaks clear enough. Six times the floor had claimed its tribute in that year alone. Two warnings ignored while dinner grew cold. These are not mere oversights but markers on a map leading to something darker in the soul of man. The law may speak of summary judgments but no judge would dare dismiss such darkness without letting light shine full upon it.

The wanting lived in her like a thing alive. It had come upon her at fourteen summers and stayed, a shadow companion through the years that followed. By seventeen it had shaped itself not into want of things but of someone, though no boy that crossed her path stirred anything in her blood. They came and went like leaves in autumn, their awkward advances scattered to wind. She studied this emptiness in herself like studying tracks in sand, theories rising and falling away like tide, none substantial enough to hold weight.

The house stood quiet most days. Her folks were peaceful people who walked soft in the world and spoke softer still. Arguments were rare as rain in drought season, save when their daughter's wild spirit pressed against the walls of their quiet life like wind through canyon walls. She carried within her a fire that burned bright against their stillness, yet it was a warmth that drew others near, not a consuming flame.

But this day carried darkness. Moving room to room seeking something unnamed she heard her mother's cry cut through the kitchen air sharp as breaking glass. She ran. Found her mother crumpled on tile like a broken bird. Pain wrapped round her mother's words tight as barbed wire. Hospital, she managed. The girl's hands found purchase, muscles remembering their training, and she bore her mother out like precious cargo through the door and into the waiting car.

The hospital air hung thick with bleach and suffering and fear but she noticed none of it, her world narrowed to her mother's pain. She carried her through doors that whispered open, voice rising raw for help. White-coated figures materialized like ghosts, wheeling out a stretcher that swallowed her mother whole. Then she was alone with the waiting.

All this because her mother had reached too high, seeking some ceramic beauty in cabinets that touched the ceiling. The stepping stool had betrayed her like false ground giving way beneath trusted feet.

The dead speak in numbers and the living count their meals. They sought truth in the eating habits of women, watching what passed their lips like priests taking count of sins. Mediterranean fare they called it. Plants and fish and oils pressed from fruits that grew in ancient soils. No potatoes. The flesh of beasts kept sparse upon their plates. Wine in moderation like a sacrament.

They had seen before how this way of eating kept death at bay. Studies writ in blood and paper showed how hearts beat longer, stronger when fed thus. The fat ones shed their burden easier this way than counting grams of lard and butter. But none had watched the brain and how it fails when vessels burst.

They gathered seventy-four thousand women and more, nurses all, scattered across eleven states like seeds in wind. For twenty years they watched them eat and die or live. Six times they made them write their testimony of meals, marking down each morsel like confessions. Most stayed true to the watching, year after year, while some vanished into the dark of time.

The counters of meals verified their methods. When death came they checked the records, the papers of hospitals, the certificates that mark a life's end. Some they called probable when proof was thin, these made up less than a quarter of the fallen.

They weighed the women, noted their smoke and pills, their monthly cycles and the hormones they took. How they moved their bodies in leisure counted too. The numbers they gathered like crows collecting bright things, seeking patterns in the chaos of living.

When the counting ended, the truth lay bare in figures cold as corpses. Two thousand hearts failed, seventeen hundred brains bled or starved, and a thousand souls departed through paths carved by broken vessels. Those who ate as the ancients did, who scored highest in their Mediterranean ways, they lived longer. The numbers spoke clear: their risk of failing hearts and minds fell by more than a quarter compared to those who ate as modern folk do.

In the end, the numbers told a story old as olive groves: how we eat marks how we die.

Hitler lives in Burma the sign said. The girl stood there holding it above her head like some proclamation of doom writ in black ink against the cardboard. She was an actor in films. The kind that made people feel good about themselves.

In the east where the sun rises red over jungle and plain there is a country of ghosts. Burma they called it once. Myanmar now. Men in uniform took it like thieves in the night. They came in 1962 with guns and proclamations and they never left. The monks rose up against them wearing robes colored like dried blood. Saffron they called it. The monks walked and they prayed and the people followed them into the streets like children following the piper. At first the men with guns watched. Then they didnt. They came in the night with their boots and their rifles and broke down the doors of the monasteries. Sacred places violated by the godless. A Japanese man with a camera died on a street corner. Just another body. They said thirteen died but a soldier who ran told different. Thousands he said. Thousands of bodies. Where they buried them no one knows.

It aint nothing new. Since man first walked upright and found he could rule over others by force there have been such things. Roman emperors who claimed divine right. Japanese kings who said they were gods themselves. Even now men who wear suits instead of crowns claim to speak for god while they deal in death.

The examples lay scattered through time like broken pottery. In China they gunned down students in a square while tanks rolled past. The government said three hundred. The truth was thousands. In Rwanda they killed with machetes, brother against brother, neighbor against neighbor. The streets ran with blood and no one came to help. And before all that there was Hitler. He killed millions. Rounded them up like cattle. Branded them. Burned them. Made them into smoke that rose up to accuse the very heavens. And now perhaps his spirit walks in Burma where the monks once walked. Where the dead lay unnamed in unmarked graves. Where the men with guns still rule.

The legacy of Duke they called Ellington ran deep through the veins of jazz like old blood through ancient stone, his years stretched long across the century and with them came power to shape sound and men alike. At the piano his touch was light as morning frost but in the writing of music he was more akin to some dark demiurge, crafting worlds of sound where men could walk free yet bound, improvising within the walls he built note by note, bar by bar. He knew these men, knew their souls and the sounds that lived in them, knew how to call forth those sounds like a conjurer of old spirits. The orchestra was his instrument and he played it like some great and terrible organ, pulling stops and pressing keys that were the very souls of men.

In the ancient tomes of Grove they speak of his Creole Love Call, how he made the human voice cry out like brass and wood, wordless and pure as desert wind. Through six circles of blues it winds, each a testament to his craft. First comes the voice against reeds like two wolves calling across valley darkness, then the muted trumpet wailing blue notes into the void. High above a clarinet keens while piano notes fall like rain beneath. The full band rises then, brass and reed locked in their eternal dance, until all culminates in a great crescendo where reeds cry out against the syncopated heartbeat of brass and rhythm. At last the voice returns, growling like some nightbound creature, before all ends in discord and darkness.

In Hot and Bothered, recorded when the moon had walked another year across the sky, he bound together the tight-wound strings of orchestration with colors drawn from the very air. Miley's trumpet called and Cox's voice answered, man and instrument trading places in some strange alchemy of sound. And when It Don't Mean a Thing rose up from silence, there was Nanton, called Tricky Sam by those who knew him, drawing forth the melody from his muted horn like an old priest reading ancient scripture, the sound of it hanging in the air like smoke from a long-dead fire.

They come to ask why things change the way they do. As if the world held answers plain and true for those who'd seek them. Back in 1917 a man called Thompson spoke of how we ain't yet learned to put numbers to the shapes of living things and truth be told we ain't much further along now neither.

The shells lay there like ancient scrolls writ in a language we barely understand. They spiral through time and space like cosmic dancers frozen in calcium carbonate, each whorl telling its own tale of life and death and change. We took to studying these Prunum shells, their ghostly forms caught in X-ray light, trying to capture their essence in numbers and equations like trying to trap starlight in a jar.

The shell grows like a living cathedral, turning through the void in perfect mathematical arcs that we ain't yet got the wisdom to fully comprehend. Each revolution marks time like the rings of a tree or the layers of earth in canyon walls. The columella stands at the center like some ancient axis mundi, holding everything together while the whorls spiral out around it like a sermon on creation itself.

You can read these shells like a book if you know how. Count the whorls from where the first suture begins, marking time in quarter turns like some cosmic clock. The aperture traces its path through space leaving behind it this perfect geometric testament to life's endless variations. Each shell carries in its form the history of its kind, written in calcium and protein, waiting for them as can read such things.

We fed these measurements into machines, trying to capture in silicon and electricity what nature had wrought in lime and water over millions of years. The numbers dance across screens like prophets speaking in tongues, telling tales of what might have been and what yet could be. But the truth of it all remains elusive, like trying to catch smoke in your hands or hold back the tide with a broom.

The dead children of Indonesia lay like fallen birds in their mothers' arms, their numbers unchanging through the years, a dark testament to a nation's struggle. Ten years passed and still they died, these small ones, while men in offices spoke of goals and targets and millennium dreams. They spoke of water flowing clean and proper places to shit but the children kept dying all the same and the mothers too, their blood flowing out across dirt floors in villages where no doctor ever set foot.

In the cities they had women who knew the old ways of birth, midwives they called them, their hands skilled in the catching of babies but helpless when the darkness came and the blood wouldn't stop. Seven of ten births they attended but it wasnt enough. Never enough. The diarrhea came for the young ones too and fewer hands reached out to help them now than before. After the births the mothers lay alone, no one watching for the fever or the bleeding that might take them in the night.

The knife that opens the belly to free the child, they called it cesarean, rare as rain in the dry season. In the cities maybe seven women in a hundred felt its mercy but in the villages only two. The poor died easier than the rich, that's how it always was and how it remained. Twenty-seven souls in a hundred turned away from the hospital door, their pockets empty as their hopes.

They argued about it in their offices with their papers and their coffee. Some said to build special programs like towers reaching to heaven, each one targeting its own kind of death. Others wanted to strengthen what was already there, the bones and sinews of the healing places. The tower-builders talked fast about quick results but they didn't speak of how their grand designs pulled the healers away from other work, how the money flowed to one place while other needs withered like crops in drought. And everywhere the paper multiplied like leaves in autumn, forms upon forms, each program demanding its own kind of truth written in its own kind of way.

The music they call Popular has grown wild and untamed these hundred years past, sprouting genres like weeds in an abandoned field till no man could count them all. And within each genre - the rap and the rock and the country and all their kin - subspecies breed and multiply like dark thoughts in a fever dream.

Heavy Metal, bastard child of rock, has perhaps grown most feral of all. Forty years it has roamed the musical wasteland, gathering darkness unto itself like a shroud. It feeds on emotion - raw and bleeding emotions that decent folk dont speak of. Early on the people saw how this beast could be trained, could be bred into new forms. And breed it did. New forms begat newer forms until the original creature was lost in the thundering herd of its progeny.

Now the beast has so many faces that men argue what truly makes the metal what it is. It has consumed other genres, digested them, made them its own. To know the thing you must go back. Back to where it first crawled from the primordial muck of music. Back to understand why they call it a movement and not just music.

Metal lives in darkness. It is a thing of excess - excess in all things. In volume and violence and theatrical display. Its practitioners are skilled beyond mere playing, they are technicians of chaos. And there are the drugs. Always the drugs. In the middle years of the seventies the drugs came like a flood and the music turned strange and otherworldly. Men made records that normal folk couldn't comprehend and blamed it on the chemicals coursing through their veins. The darkness in it was new. Popular music hadn't known such shadows before. Later metal drew from the old Romantics, those who knew darkness too. Even the Beatles, those clean-cut boys, succumbed. Their Helter Skelter was among the first, a response to the Stones' own darkness. They wanted to prove they could walk in those shadows too.

In the years before the dreamers took to their canvases with their strange visions the man called Rousseau had already begun to paint his own dreams both in sleep and in waking. The Dream came in 1910 and in it lay not just some woman struck dumb by the savage beauty of a dreamed land but the very essence of Rousseau's own yearnings wrought in oils and pigments. He had long sought the approval of those who deemed themselves fit to judge such things, those who spoke in hushed tones in gilded halls about what made art worthy and what did not. And in this seeking he found himself torn between two paths, each stretching out before him like roads in some dark wood. One path led to mimicry and conformity, the other to a wild independence that knew no masters.

The man himself came into this world on May 21, 1844, in Laval, a town that squatted in the northwestern reaches of France. His father worked metal and sold hardware, living well enough by the standards of those days. The boy learned no art save what his own hands taught him and for forty years he collected tolls for the state, a gabelou they called him though some named him douanier which was not right but stuck to him all the same. His first wife Clémence passed into whatever darkness awaits us all, following eight babes who never drew breath long enough to know the world. Only Julia remained, his daughter, while grief sat heavy upon him like some ancient stone. He turned to painting then as a man turns to water in the desert, seeking salvation in the sweep of brush against canvas.

Unlike the others who painted in those days, men who made the peasants into something fine and noble in their pictures, Rousseau painted what he knew and dreamed what common men dream. He worked in the shadow of giants, men like Matisse who had learned their craft in proper schools and whose names carried weight in the salons where such things mattered. Gordon wrote that Matisse feared painting like others painted while Rousseau wanted nothing more than to paint so well and true that the Artiste Français would welcome him into their ranks. But such things were not to be, not then, not in the way he hoped.

They say truth and beauty walk together like old companions on a dusty road and maybe they do. The great minds spoke of it and wrote of it in their books and papers yellowed now with age, their words fading like the memories of dead men. Keats knew it when he wrote of that old urn, speaking truth to beauty and beauty back to truth in some eternal dance that none could parse nor need to.

We learn what we know from books and life and pain but these things, these twin spirits of right and beautiful, they come to us like night comes to the desert. No teacher showed us how. No mother pointed to a sunset and said here child this is beauty mark it well. We know it in our bones like ancient things know the earth.

You can write about why something's right or wrong or beautiful or damned but the words just scatter like birds from a field when the truth of it comes round. Take that painting of the woman with the smile. Men have spent lifetimes talking about shadow and light and what lies behind those eyes but none of it tells you why it catches in your throat when you stand before it. There's something else there. Something that won't be caught in words no matter how fine the net we weave.

O'Connor knew it. Said a story was the only way to tell some truths and even then the telling wasn't complete. Like trying to describe the taste of water to a man who's never drunk. Wittgenstein too, though he used bigger words to say the same thing. That ethics lives somewhere beyond where words can reach.

And there's the heart of it. The moral and the beautiful, they live in that space between what we can say and what we can know. Like old ghosts that we can feel but never touch. That's why books carry such weight with us. They're not just words on pages but mirrors of the soul, showing us what's right and wrong in ways we can't explain but know deep in that place where knowing starts. They carry values like a river carries water, flowing through us, shaping us, but never quite letting us hold them still enough to study.

The Germany that stands now rises like some ancient colossus, its borders drawn in blood and stone from the shadow-wreathed peaks of München to the cold gray waters of Kiel where the Baltic laps at shores old as memory itself. This land speaks with one voice, though its tongue differs from the Rhine-blessed Köln through the heartland to Dresden where the Elbe cuts its path like a steel thread through time. That such a place should birth itself from many wombs seems ordained, written in the very soil that bore the tribes of old.

In the time before time Germania lay vast and dark, its name a whispered thing that scholars still war over like ravens fighting for carrion. Tacitus, that Roman chronicler of blood and conquest, spoke of the Tungrians who bore the name German before crossing the Rhine to wage their war against the Gauls. Caesar too marked these people in his accounts, dipping his pen in both ink and blood to tell of the Germanic hordes that crossed the great river with malice in their hearts. He borrowed their name from Gaulish tongues, marking those he'd broken from those who still stood free beyond his reach. Some say the word meant neighbor in that ancient speech, while others claim it spoke of the spear they carried, the ger, or maybe it came from Irish words meaning to cry out, as if the very name could capture the battle-howls of a people who knew nothing but war.

Tacitus wrote of them again in his Germania, claiming them pure as winter snow, untouched by foreign blood or strange customs. Who indeed, he asked, would leave warm southern lands for this raw country where the sky itself seemed to wage war on those below? What man would choose such a place unless it was already burned into his bones?

And Rome, that great devourer of lands and men, sent its legions north but never truly claimed these forests and marshlands as their own. They came for amber and iron, for slaves and glory, but always they returned south, leaving the Germanic tribes to their own devices. These people dwelt in the shadow of empire, trading goods torn from the earth and the strength of their sword arms in service to Rome's eagles, but they remained their own masters, waiting in the dark forests for their time to come.

The shadows of deception run deep in Twelfth Night where masks and falsehoods serve their purpose until they don't and a soul must cast off its borrowed skin lest it be forever lost in the dark corridors of its own making. There aint no easy way back from such deceptions neither. A body finds itself cast out standing alone in the cold world of truth having to choose between keeping what's left of their own self or holding onto them that's around them. Some folk take kindly to learning they been fooled while others carry that betrayal like a wound that won't heal.

When it comes to them that choose to wear the clothes of the opposite sex the matter gets darker still. The question that haunts like a ghost in an empty room is why. Why does a person turn their back on what God gave them to take up false dress. With Viola we know. She speaks it plain: "I'll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count..." The words hang there like a confession.

Being cast upon strange shores Viola done what she had to do to keep breathing in a world that would sooner see her dead. Her deception worked right enough but it cut her off from her own kind leaving her to walk alone among women who couldn't know her true self. And then there's Olivia who looks at her with eyes full of love meant for Sebastian: "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." The weight of it all bears down harder still when Orsino speaks words that cut like knives: "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me."

Them that read this tale now might see something different in it. Might see how lies can sometimes dig up truths that were buried deep. Olivia and Orsino both carry something inside them that Viola's presence forces into the light. Whether Olivia loves Cesario cause she sees a man or cause something else stirs in her blood aint clear but Shakespeare seems to be mocking them that judge only by what their eyes tell them.

You can see it plain when Olivia turns her love from Cesario to Sebastian quick as a prairie fire jumping track and starts calling Viola sister instead of lover: "A sister, you are she." The words fall final like stones in still water.

They spoke of German rule in those lands with a darkness in their eyes. Tales of blood and bone scattered across African plains. The Ovaherero. The Nama. Names that echoed like hollow bells in the void of their extinction. But empires aint never been simple things to reckon with and this one sprawled across the earth like some great dying beast, each limb moving to its own rhythm, each claw marking the soil different from the last.

In the east they found them reading. Black faces bent over books in the harsh light, words swimming before their eyes like strange fish in deeper waters. The British came in 1919 and found what the Germans had built there. Schools standing like sentinels in the dust. But south and west it was different. There the missionaries walked alone among the people, government coin scarce in their pockets while white children sat in proper schools built with proper means.

The land there was different too. Not the killing heat of other territories but something more temperate, more forgiving to European blood. By 1913 they numbered fifteen thousand, these pale riders in a foreign land. More than anywhere else in that scattered empire. They built their world there atop the old one, like layers of sediment pressing down through time.

The books tell it different ways. German words stacked in neat rows speaking of systems and methods, of civilizing missions in distant lands. Later came the English writers, comparing one piece of earth against another, measuring success in literacy rates and school attendance like counting cattle at auction. Cohen wrote of it too, saying the whites who settled there shaped everything that came after, their presence heavy as lead in the African soil.

But the truth of it was simpler and harder both. In some places knowledge flowed like water and in others it dried up in the sun, leaving nothing but bare earth and forgotten promises. That was the way of empires. That was the way of men.

They stood there at the border, these two nations, like ancient enemies carved from the same stone. From 1836 to 1893 they warred and watched each other across that line drawn in blood and dust. Fifty-seven years. The war came in 46 and when it was done Mexico lay bleeding and the victor claimed Texas and all the southwest territories like a great carrion bird picking clean the bones of the defeated.

They fought as men have always fought, for land and pride and the old hatreds that sleep in the hearts of nations. The Americans and the Mexicans carried within them the seeds of their discord - religion, culture, the weight of history itself pressing down upon them like a stone. As it has always been with nations that share borders, that invisible line drawn across the earth became a wound that would not heal.

In those times the Americans feared what lay south as they had once feared the old specters of their colonial past - Catholicism, monarchy, the Spanish crown that had ruled these lands before them. Like their cold war with the Soviets that would come later, though this was different. This was older. This was blood.

Seventeen times they clashed in those fifty-seven years. Bandits and raiders crossed that line drawn in sand, ghosting across the desert night to strike at border towns. Both sides sent soldiers to guard that boundary but still the blood flowed. The raids continued until both nations brought their armies to bear, two giants facing each other across the void.

But time changes all things. Mexico grew dependent on its northern neighbor, like a wounded animal learning to trust the hand that once struck it. The American hunger changed too, from land to money, from conquest to commerce. The old hatred faded like tracks in the desert sand, but the memory remained, etched in the bones of both lands.

The sickness came without warning like some dark rider in the night. Fifteen years past now. I was a nurse then, having chose that path not from want but from need, the kind that grows deep in your bones when you've known nothing but want as a child. They'd say you'll never want for work, folk'll always be sick and dying. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up with the healing arts instead.

Then there I was. Forty-six years lived and alone in the world save for what little I earned and now even that was gone. Fifteen years lived on government mercy and everything I ever called mine has scattered to the wind like autumn leaves. Each dawn brings its own war against fear and pride. Nothing certain now cept uncertainty itself. Yet this truth remains: without the charity of blood kin and them few true friends I'd have been dead or worse. When calamity comes it strips a body of all pretense of strength.

Ain't no man can outrun disaster forever. No matter how you fortify against it some things just too big for one soul to weather alone. The government basket's got holes and the bottom's bout to give way but I'd sooner see Americans learning to trust their neighbor again than watch em all dig separate holes in the ground like scared rabbits.

They talk bout rugged individualism like it was some kind of gospel truth but what kept our ancestors breathing weren't going it alone. It was breaking bread together and sharing what little they had. Them wagon trains that crossed the mountains didn't make it on account of lone wolves but because they moved as one.

So yeah, keep your disaster kit. Your pure water tablets and window tape and matches that'll light in a flood. Stack your canned goods high if you got the space. Plant your garden if the good Lord gave you dirt to plant in. But while you're doing all that surviving, might want to learn your neighbor's name. Cause when the real trouble comes, and it will come, ain't no man an island worth living on.

In the old world, before the time of iron and steel and the great machines that would come to rule the earth, there was born a prince. He who would later be known as Buddha. The ancient scrolls speak of his coming in the fifth or sixth century before the Christ child and how he cast aside the riches of his station to wander the dusty roads of existence until enlightenment found him like a thief in the night. His words spread like wildfire through the dry grass of men's souls and from these words came Buddhism, its oldest and most pure form being what men call Theravada.

Twenty five hundred years have passed since then. The religion stands transformed like a tree that has weathered countless storms, its branches twisted by time and circumstance. In Sri Lanka they still perform the water-cutting ceremony, though Buddha himself never spoke of such things. Monks in saffron robes and common folk alike gather at the waters edge, their faces reflecting in the dark surface like ancient memories. The changes run deeper than mere ceremony. They run to the very marrow of what the religion means and what it promises to those who follow its path.

The changes came from within and without, like wounds that both fester and heal. Some brought by those who walked the path and some by those who stood against it. Some meant to destroy and others changed things without meaning to, like a child who breaks a pottery vessel while reaching for water.

These forces that shaped the faith came in pairs like dark riders on the horizon. Internal and external. One born of the faithful, be they monk or layman, and one from those who stood outside the walls of belief. Some came with knives drawn and hatred in their hearts, seeking to cut down what Buddha had built. Others came without malice, changing things by their mere presence like wind shapes stone. All these forces moved through the world like spirits, leaving their mark on the faith that Buddha left behind.

The heart of it beats still. The triple gem they call it: Buddha, Dhamma, Sangha. The Dhamma holds the ancient words in three vessels - the Suttas with their teachings, the Vinaya with its laws, and the Abhidhamma with its truths about the nature of all things. They speak of Anatta - the absence of soul, of Dukkha - the suffering that walks with all living things, and of Anicca - how nothing endures. Only by seeing these truths can one break free from Sansara, the great wheel of death and rebirth that turns like a millstone grinding souls to dust. When the wheel stops, so too do the three poisons: desire that burns like fever, hatred cold as stone, and delusion that clouds the mind like river mist.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
