Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
Culture moves like a shadow through the rooms where men gather to strike their bargains. It aint what you might call a thing you can hold in your hand nor measure with any tool made by man. It lives in the spaces between words and in the silences that follow them. They say all Russians is stubborn and all Japanese bend like reeds in the wind but such notions is for children and fools who aint never set foot beyond their own fenceline.

The truth of it lies deeper, like groundwater in limestone country. A man comes to foreign soil carrying his own truth like a tattered map, trying to overlay it on ground that won't conform. Some study histories writ in blood and bone, others parse out ancient grievances passed down like family silver. But judgment aint worth the breath spent speaking it. You got to take the world as it lays before you, especially when you come to the table with a weaker hand. And if youre standing on someone else's ground you best mind their ways or find yourself alone with your principles.

Corporate culture aint no different from tribal custom, just younger and dressed in better cloth. Some outfits work their people like ranch horses, others let em graze easy. You see it in their clothes and in how they speak to one another, whether they pass orders down like military command or let em float like dandelion seeds. Even in one company the culture shifts like weather from city to prairie, from coast to heartland. Some folk think certain cultures is all of one piece but that's just the surface of deep water.

Values is the bedrock under it all. They tell you why a man will smile while losing or fight to the death over a word spoke wrong. In some places saving face matters more than profit and in others the deal is everything. A smart man learns these things before he sets foot in the room. But smarter still is the one who knows his opponent as a man and not just a shape cast by culture's long shadow.

He'd read it there in the old book, written in ink now faded and brown upon pages thin as onionskin. The fool hath said in his heart there is no God. Words from Psalm fourteen and again in the writings of Anselm, that old saint who'd wrestled with the very notion of divine existence like Jacob with his angel in the dark. And after him came Thomas, called Aquinas, both men seeking to pin down with words what could not be captured by mere language alone.

They were hunters of the same prey, these two, though their methods differed as night from day. To compare them proper we must accept their quarry as real, their God as true - not some shapeless deity conjured by philosophers but the God of scripture, terrible and magnificent. Yet neither man, for all their wisdom, could lay bare the full truth of it.

Anselm's way was the way of the inner eye, searching the depths of understanding like a man might search a well for his own reflection. His argument ran thus: that God exists in the mind and therefore must exist in truth, for how can the mind conceive of that which cannot be? A circular path perhaps, like a dog chasing its tail, yet not without its own strange logic. Faith seeking understanding, he called it. As if understanding itself was a creature that could be hunted down and caught.

But Thomas would have none of this inner searching. He was a man of the world, of stone and flesh and bone. His God left tracks in the physical world, footprints that any man with eyes could follow. Five trails he mapped out: change, cause, necessity, perfection, and the great dance of creation itself. Like a man finding a dead fire and knowing by the ash and coal that someone had been there before him. No faith required, he said. Just eyes to see and a mind to reason.

They were both right and both wrong, these ancient hunters of truth. Like blind men describing an elephant, each touching a different part and swearing they knew the whole of it. But the truth was bigger than either of them knew, and remains so still.

Writers lay their words like traps in the dark. Some catch their prey and some dont. Fitzgerald he laid his words careful like in that book about Gatsby. Sometimes he would take two words that had no business being together and wed them anyway like a shotgun marriage in some backwater town. Other times he'd pick up some thing, could be anything, and make it mean something else entirely. Like colors. Gold and green and white and red and all manner of hues that aint just hues no more but carriers of meaning dark as blood.

In that book about Gatsby he took to using white and gray and red like they was omens. White and gray especially. They wasnt just colors no more but became like ghosts of meaning floating through them pages. White meant sameness but with money behind it. Gray was sameness gone to seed.

He planted these meanings early like spring wheat. Everyone wearing white like they was all cut from the same bolt of cloth. Daisy and that Jordan girl always in white and Nick in his white flannels and Tom in his white shirt and Catherine with her face all powdered white as bone. Only time the white gives way is at Gatsby's party where the colors run wild and primitive like animals let loose from their cages.

The whiteness and the grayness they spread like a sickness. Down in them canyons of New York all white and dead. The names of party people gone gray as ash on Nick's paper. Apartment buildings stacked like slices of white bread nobody wanted. Plain folk and plain places all marked with it too. Them two girls Jordan and Daisy with their white childhood that wasnt no different from any other childhood. Gray cars and gray land in that valley where ashes fall like dirty snow. That Italian child by the tracks gray as a shadow and the old man selling dogs gray as time itself.

Once he'd loaded them colors with all that weight he turned them loose again. Used them like a man uses a knife. When Daisy comes back wearing white in her white car she aint a woman no more but just another piece of sameness Gatsby's been chasing. Like trying to catch smoke in your hands. Her fur collar gray as a morning fog and that white dress before the showdown between Tom and Gatsby. All of it marking her as something less than real. Something uniform and empty as an echo in an empty room.

The land lies blessed by sun and mild days, a country where men have wrought sustenance from soil since time out of mind. Here the earth gives forth its bounty - tomatoes swollen red as blood, citrus hanging like small suns, the green leaves of lettuce spread like hands reaching skyward. Squash and broccoli and herbs. The peach trees and the lemon trees. The berries dark as night. The bees making their sweet gold. And the peppers that burn like fire in the mouth.

They call it San Diego County and here the people hunger for clean food, food grown without poison, waiting in long lines to claim their share. They come for eggs still warm from the nest and milk sweet from the udder. They walk the land where their food is born, watching birds wheel overhead and treading paths worn by countless feet before them.

The land speaks of older things. One hundred sixty acres pressed against the Cleveland Forest like a child to its mother's breast. Chaparral and grassland brought by ships from across the sea, oak trees that were saplings when the first white men came. Before them the Indians walked here, numberless generations leaving nothing but flakes of stone and shards of pottery to mark their passing. Then came the cattlemen and the woodcutters, their descendants still working the land that great-grandfathers claimed with paper and ink and the sweat of their brows.

Here now the farmers work without chemicals, their hands callused and backs bent, fighting weeds and insects as old as time. The cost is dear - more work, more loss, more struggle against the ancient enemies of those who till the soil. But the land remembers. Where poison once flowed now butterflies dance and birds sing. The kangaroo rat, small as a child's fist, makes its home in burrows beneath the earth. The yellow-legged frog still leaves its spawn in clear waters. The gnatcatcher flits through branches like a ghost.

They have programs now, men in offices who would help preserve these things. They offer money and knowledge, as if such things could capture the essence of this place where the wild and tame meet like old friends across a fence.

Blood runs thick between brothers. Runs like dark water through the veins of time itself, carrying with it all manner of things both sacred and profane. Love and hate and pride dwelling there like ancient creatures in some lightless deep. Brothers know each other in ways that others cannot know, seeing in the other's face a mirror of their own soul, raw and unvarnished in the harsh light of truth. When darkness comes it comes swift and merciless, and in that darkness the true nature of brotherhood reveals itself like some terrible dawn.

They was two brothers in this tale. One strong and one weak, moving through a world painted in colors of decay and redemption. The weak one they called Doodle, born with a heart that fluttered like a dying bird in his chest. The strong one, he wanted what brothers want - someone to race against the wind, to climb the twisted vines that hung like hanged men in Old Woman Swamp, to sit high in the pine trees where the air runs thin and watch the world below turn to shadow.

Pride is a poison that works slow but sure. The older brother carried it in him like a serpent coiled round his heart. He looked at Doodle and saw all the things that could never be, all the dreams that died stillborn. There was nights he stood over the child with a pillow in his hands, death hovering in the room like smoke. But then the baby smiled and something broke inside him, some dark thing washed away by a love he didn't know he carried. That smile was like God striking a match in the darkness of his soul.

The land stretched out before them green and wild, indifferent to their struggles. Through it they moved like pilgrims seeking something they couldn't name, the older brother driving them both toward some terrible reckoning. Pride and love wrestled in his heart like Jacob with the angel, but pride is a hard master and takes no prisoners. In the end only one brother would walk away from that green cathedral, carrying with him the weight of all that was and all that could have been.

The mind of man is a dark and labyrinthine thing, wrought with complexities that defy the simplest notions of understanding. Through the long years of our knowing, we have sought to capture its essence in metaphor, like trying to trap shadows in a box. First came the tablets of wax, then the papyrus leaves yellowed with age, then bound pages, and now in these modern times we speak of circuits and silicon, though none of these tell the whole truth of it.

The way of knowing begins in the flesh itself, where the world's raw touch becomes something else entirely, transformed like bread into sustenance, like light into seeing. These signals course through the corridors of the brain like refugees fleeing some nameless war, moving both upward and downward through the neural wilderness. When a man looks upon a black box against white, his mind assembles it piece by piece, like a carpenter building a coffin - first the edges, then the shadows, then the whole dark shape of it. The mind knows what it knows before it knows it knows, reaching down through layers of knowing to grasp at understanding.

There exists a filter in the mind, ancient as stone, that sorts what matters from what does not. A man walking across grass need not count each blade, though each blade sends its message upward through his boots and into his brain. Yet his own name spoken in a crowd will reach his ears like a gunshot across still water. The mind keeps its own counsel on what to heed and what to discard.

Memory is not one thing but many, like a house with many rooms, each holding different treasures. Some memories pass like smoke, others linger like rust on iron. Words themselves are stored in different ways - their shape, their sound, their meaning - each aspect laid down in the brain's dark matter like layers of sediment in ancient rock. Some memories circle like wolves in the mind for twenty seconds before vanishing, while others embed themselves in the very protein of being, becoming part of the flesh itself.

Men have made maps of knowledge in the brain, drawing borders and connections like surveyors of an unexplored country. They speak of networks where ideas touch each other like strands in a spider's web - chair touching table touching wood touching tree, each connected to each in an endless chain of meaning. But these are just maps, and the territory they describe remains wild and unknowable as the desert night.

They called it the great unraveling. In the year of our Lord 2007 the markets fell and with them fell the dreams and hopes of a nation. Like some terrible god casting judgment upon the wicked and the righteous alike. The jobless walked the streets in growing numbers and houses stood empty like the bleached bones of dead things in the sun. The great towers of commerce that had stood like monuments to man's industry now wavered and some fell entirely.

The seeds of this devastation had been sown in years prior. In the time of Clinton when men in suits spoke of prosperity eternal and the common man's right to own his patch of earth. They fashioned strange instruments of debt and commerce, Byzantine in their complexity. Papers that promised wealth built upon wealth that was never there. Like some dark alchemy they transmuted simple homes into gold and then into ash.

The banks and the men who ran them created things they called adjustable-rate mortgages and collateralized debt obligations. Words that meant nothing to the common man but would come to mean everything. They built their tower of debt higher and higher until it scraped the very heavens, never thinking that such towers must someday fall.

And fall they did. In the year 2007 the great houses of finance - Bear Stearns, Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers, names that had once seemed eternal as mountains - began to crumble. Four trillion in debts, a number so vast it ceased to have meaning. Like watching a great fire consume everything in its path. The government men came with their papers and their promises but they could no more stop what was coming than they could stop the sun from setting. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, those twin pillars of the American dream, fell into the hands of the government like wounded animals being led to shelter. But there was no shelter from what was coming. No shelter at all.

The exposition comes like a thief in the night. Silent and merciless. Writers set their words loose upon the page like wild horses, proud and gleaming with sweat, but the reader sees only shadows moving across empty plains. They turn away. They curse. The doctor woman who speaks of these things has been known to rage at her screen, her voice echoing in the empty room like thunder in a canyon.

No friend is exposition. No friend at all.

Show dont tell, they say. Ancient wisdom passed down through the ages like scripture. But even the wisest among us fall prey to the darkness of endless words. Words that pile up like dead leaves in autumn, choking the life from stories that might have lived. Two devils sit on the shoulders of those who write. One whispers of histories that must be told, while the other speaks of childhoods that stretch back beyond memory. Both are liars.

Exposition is death. It is the telling of things in simple words when the showing would suffice. In the moving pictures they call films, it comes when one man speaks to another of things they both already know, like an old mariner cursed to tell his tale again and again until judgment day.

Consider the woman and the man she loved. Their meeting, their marriage, their ending. Two pages of words that tell nothing of the truth. No voice between them save for four lines shared like crumbs at a feast. The reader needs more. Needs to see how he looked at her across crowded rooms, how his hands moved when he spoke of things he loved, how she changed when he entered her world like sunlight through stained glass. Without these things the murder means nothing. Just more words on a page growing cold.

A story needs meat on its bones. But writers grow weary. They rush past truth seeking shortcuts through the darkness. They say: here is a man who flew war machines, who tends to automobiles in the night hours, who married twice and spawned no children, who dreams of owning his small kingdom of gasoline and oil, who breaks his fast with eggs served on bread and sauce. But these are just words. And words without blood are dead things.

The morning news came cold and stark across the screen like some prophetic vision of mankind's darker nature. First came word from Ashley where a man named Hostettler had put knife to wife, the blade rising and falling in that ancient dance of violence that men have known since time was young. His face on the screen was a mask of evil, eyes black and hollow like windows into hell itself.

Then came news of the boy Buyers, just eighteen summers old, shot down in Sharon Woods where the darkness holds its own counsel. SWAT teams moved through the shadows like armored priests performing last rites, but no killer was found. The story passed quick like a ghost, as such tales often do when the dead or dying wear dark skin, while other victims, pale as morning frost, command the airwaves like royalty.

A hole appeared in the sky itself, or rather in the metal bird that carried healing angels. Some fool with a twentytwo had put lead through the helicopter's skin. Five thousand dollars hung in the air like bait for someone's conscience.

The weatherman spoke of rain coming, storms building in the west like God's own artillery. Numbers rolled off his tongue - eighties, percentages, probabilities - all of it meaning nothing to the thunder that was coming.

Then came the tale of the UDF store on Clime Road, where a dark man in darker clothes had come for money not his own. They spoke of his blackness like it was a sin itself, dwelling on the shade of his skin as if evil had its own color.

Last was the Mexican druglord Rodriguez, condemned to three hundred months in steel and concrete. The numbers fell strange, as if years weren't enough to measure a man's punishment. They marked him Hispanic like a brand, though what that meant in the vast arithmetic of justice wasn't clear.

All these stories scrolled past like scenes from some greater apocalyptic narrative, each one a testament to the violence and prejudice that runs through the world like poison in the groundwater.

They called them ETFs. Securities that moved like shadows across the electronic plains, tracking indices and commodities and baskets of assets like some dark harbinger of wealth or ruin. They traded like stocks but carried within them a multitude, a diversification that men sought after like water in the desert. A man could buy one share or sell short or leverage his position with borrowed money, all while paying less than what the mutual fund lords demanded for their services.

Yet there were costs. Always costs. Commissions that must be paid like blood tribute to the brokers who facilitated such trades. But the variety was vast, stretching across markets like an endless prairie of financial instruments, each promising its own salvation.

We set out to study one such beast, the IHF, to determine if its promise of diversification was truth or mere illusion cast upon the screens of traders. We would compare it against its ten largest holdings, those stocks that made up nearly two-thirds of its being, to see if a man might do better to hold them separate rather than bound together in this modern financial construct.

The mathematics of it was brutal and cold. We took only the top ten holdings, for to include all would be to venture into madness. These ten represented 63.58 percent of the whole, like the strongest warriors in an army of many.

The calculations spread before us like entrails, telling their own truth. Returns and betas laid bare on paper, showing that these ten stocks alone might yield more bounty than their collective form, with less risk coursing through their veins. The difference stood at 6.11 percent, no small matter in a world where men killed for less.

But numbers can lie, or at least mislead, like mirages in the financial desert. We needed more. We needed to know if these differences were real or merely phantoms dancing in the statistical light. So we dug deeper, into the standard deviations of each holding, normalizing them like preparing bodies for burial, to compare them against the whole of IHF itself.

The numbers fell hard that third month, like winter birds shot from a cold gray sky. You could see it there in Figure 17 plain as death. The kind of fall that makes a man question everything he thought he knew. Winter had come to New England the way it always does, merciless and raw, and the bicycles that once crowded the racks stood abandoned like the bones of prehistoric beasts. The people who'd walked now drove. Who could blame them. December brought with it the end of things, the way December always does. Papers needed grading and the holidays loomed like specters and the students scattered to the four winds, carrying with them whatever enthusiasm they'd had for our little crusade.

They came back in January but the fire was gone. February was worse. Maybe that's just the way of things in this world. The bright flame burns quick and hot then gutters out leaving nothing but ash and memory. We tried to rekindle it come March with what we called the Carpool Challenge Week, a desperate gambit that worked after its fashion, though nothing burns quite the same the second time around.

But there was something deeper at work, something woven into the fabric of who we are as a people. The car is freedom. The car is power. The car is America herself, and who were we to try to break that covenant. We offered what bribes we could - gift cards for coffee and books and food, the small indulgences that make life bearable. But perhaps we should have thought bigger. A bicycle maybe. A hybrid car gleaming in the sun. An electric vehicle humming with promise. The sort of prize that makes a man's eyes go wide and his heart beat faster. Maybe then they would have stayed with us through the dark months. Maybe then the numbers wouldn't have fallen like they did, like dead leaves in autumn, like hope in winter.

We could have built it up slow, like a fire you mean to last the night. Start with the small things, then the bicycles, then finally the car itself, a beacon drawing them back to us. But we didn't. We stayed our course and watched the numbers fall and now we know better. Now we know what it takes to fight against the current of human nature, to swim upstream against the river of American dreams.

They were there in the darkness of the archives, those ancient reels of celluloid, fifteen in number, spanning the years from 1895 to 1901, each bearing Edison's mark. Magic boxes containing illusions wrought not by God but by man's own devilry with the machine. I watched them all, every flickering frame, studying their nature like some pilgrim seeking truth in sacred texts.

These phantoms danced upon the screen bound by rules older than the medium itself. They moved in their fixed space like creatures caught between worlds, trapped in a proscenium arch that served as both window and prison. The camera stood witness, unmoved and unmoving, capturing figures that dared not approach it, as if held back by some invisible force that commanded their sideways dance.

Take that tale they called Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel, made in the last year of the old century. Josh and his kind moved like clockwork figures on their horizontal track, entering stage right like players in some mechanical theatre, never daring to breach the invisible wall between their world and ours. The camera watched, patient and merciless in its fixed gaze.

These moving pictures bore the bloodline of the theatre, that ancient art that kept its performers at arms length from those who watched. No face ever loomed large upon the screen, no eye ever pierced the veil between player and viewer. They kept their distance, these ghosts of light, performing their tricks in long shot or medium frame, never closer, never intimate.

Most curious was how these mechanical dreams confined themselves to single breaths, one shot containing all there was to tell, rarely stretching beyond sixty seconds of life. Yet even in this brevity there lay deception. What appeared whole was oftentimes stitched together from separate pieces, like a corpse reassembled for viewing. The Execution of Mary showed this truth plain enough - watch close and you'll see where they cut more than just the queen's head, splicing reality itself to serve their illusion.

These were our first lies told in light, our first attempts to make the impossible real through the sorcery of the machine. And like all lies, they held their own peculiar truth.

The Gothic Novel stands as both old and new, a thing that carries within it the seeds of its own contradiction. Like some ancient tomb unearthed in modern soil it bears the weight of ages past while speaking to those who would dig it up anew. Ian Watt called it what it was. An oxymoron. Old-New. And men have praised it and damned it in equal measure, some saying it held no depth while others spoke of Burke's terrible sublime like preachers speaking of divine revelation.

When Horace Walpole birthed the first true Gothic tale in The Castle of Otranto he didnt know what dark thing he had loosed upon the world. He took the ancient ways of romance and wedded them to something modern and in doing so created a bastard child that would outlive its father. The theatrical elements of old merged with what men called the mimicry of nature and from this union came what Walpole himself named A Gothic Story. The word gothic itself had been worn smooth by time and use, passed through countless mouths to describe peoples and buildings and times long dead. Some saw it as primitive. Backward. A thing best left in the past while society marched ever forward into what they called progress. But the marriage of theatrical gothic elements with the psychological intimacy of the novel created something that refused to die, that was somehow both ancient and newborn with each reading.

The ghost of chivalry haunts these pages like a revenant that cannot rest. In Otranto the medieval notions of knightly virtue are both preserved and transformed, like a body that has been both mummified and mutilated. Walpole and his kind clung to these ideals of the brave and honorable knight precisely because such men had vanished from the world, if they had ever truly existed at all. The gothic past became a dream of something better, a time when men knew honor and duty and did not shy from either. Walpole wrote in dark times, when politics had grown foul and accusations flew like carrion birds. Perhaps he thought that something fundamental had been lost, some essential goodness that had once lived in men's hearts but had withered and died in the modern world. We see this most clearly in Frederic, a character who carries the weight of chivalric virtue like a crown of thorns. He comes to us first in description, a prince who has known suffering, who has walked away from tragedy, who men believe fell fighting the infidel. The gallant and courteous Knight exists in these pages as something larger than life, excessive in his virtue as all things in Gothic tales must be excessive.

Supply chain it moves like a river through the land of commerce. Raw materials to finished goods flowing ever onward to the waiting hands of customers who know not from whence it came. In 1982 a man called Oliver gave name to this thing that had existed nameless since the first trader walked the first road with the first goods. He called it supply chain management and in doing so he captured the essence of planning and control and implementation that feeds the hunger of want.

Six pillars hold up this temple of commerce. Production. Supply. Inventory. Location. Transportation. Information. Like ancient gods they stand watch over the flow of goods, and the men who tend to business bow before them seeking favor in the marketplace.

Production stands first among these, a cornerstone laid deep in the bedrock of enterprise. It asks the questions that must be answered. When. Why. Where. How. The managers peer into the great void of the marketplace like seers reading entrails, seeking signs of what the people want. The market speaks in whispers of demand and they must listen close to hear its truth. Then they must decide what will be born into the world and in what numbers and from which wombs of industry it will come forth.

I knew this truth when I worked the floors of Walmart and Target both. There was a scripture for everything. How to dress. How to move. How to receive the great trucks that came like metal beasts in the night bearing their cargo. Everything written down in books like industrial bibles telling all who would read them the proper way of things.

Supply comes next in the procession. It speaks of capabilities and partnerships and the breaking of whole things into parts. Managers must look upon their domains and know which pieces fit where like some great industrial puzzle. Sometimes they must reach out beyond their walls to other makers and other doers, seeking that thing called velocity. Velocity that promises quality and flexibility while keeping the coin in the purse, though few who seek it truly find it.

They were books of another time. Victorian they called them. All manner and detail laid out like bones in the desert sun, bleached white with aristocratic concern and societal affairs that meant nothing to the dead or dying. But there were others. Different ones. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights stood apart like dark sentinels in the gathering dusk, their pages filled with a mystery that crawled beneath the skin like fever dreams. They bore witness to things that proper society dared not speak of.

In one such passage the boy Oliver walks through a fevered haze. He walks with killers. With Sikes and Crackit who argue in voices that echo through his skull like gunshots in an empty church. The words come and go like wind through dead grass. Then the real shots ring out and the night explodes in fire and screaming and lights that dance like devil-moths against his eyes. Some force, nameless and terrible, drags him through the chaos while pain gnaws at him like a starved dog that won't let go.

These fever dreams run through both books like dark water through underground caves. In Oliver's tale they show what lies beneath, the rot and the fear and the helplessness of a child caught in the machinery of fate. When the shooting comes back to him in the twenty-eighth chapter it comes like a visitation, like something holy and terrible both. The boy relives it all while his body searches for salvation it dont believe in. He's powerless. Always was. The pain aint even a surprise no more, just a companion walking beside him in the dark. The question aint about who shot him. The question is about whose will brought the boy to this place, because it sure wasnt his own. Old Fagin had worked his poison deep, wearing down the boy's spirit like water wearing down stone until there wasnt nothing left but acceptance of the dark.

Time itself becomes a stranger. Day passes into night or maybe there never was a day at all. Just darkness bleeding into darkness while silence stretches out like a rope with no end.

Years back I worked with the young ones after their schooling was done for the day. Small faces bent over books and papers in the late afternoon light. Most I could help well enough but reading and words were what I knew best. There was this boy called Adrian, might have been eight or nine, who couldn't read worth a damn. Something wasnt right with how he saw the letters. Some he knew like old friends and others may as well have been hieroglyphs scratched in ancient stone. His English was pure as mountain water but his blood was Mexican sure enough. We fought those letters like they were demons until the day his mother came.

She walked in while I was minding the stragglers left behind from some excursion. Not a word of English passed her lips, just rapid-fire Spanish like soft bullets. My own Spanish was poor and broken but we made do with gestures and half-understood words. That's when the truth hit me like a hammer blow. Adrian could read just fine. It was our strange English letters that were foreign to him, not the words themselves. Whether that knowledge ever served him I cannot say.

I tell this tale because it speaks to something deeper, something that runs through the veins of our schools here in California like a dark current. The wall between languages aint always what you'd expect. Even a child who speaks English pure as springwater might stumble when the letters dance strange on the page. We all know this devil exists but the killing of it aint so simple. For Adrian the medicine was clear enough - teach him our letters, teach him our sounds. But for them that barely speak English the cure aint so clean. No single answer exists in this world or the next. Dual language learning, throwing them in the deep end, private teaching, special English classes - none of these alone will slay the beast. The truth lies in using them all like weapons in an arsenal.

The dual language way of teaching aint just for the Spanish speakers but for all our young ones. Studies show these children rise above their peers like hawks over field mice. Some folk fear it's wasteful, that most children won't gain nothing from it. That's a lie black as pitch. If we made this the way instead of the exception, every child would grow stronger for it. But how to do it? Force every teacher to speak two tongues? No, that's a fool's errand. But having them that can speak both languages helping in the classroom, that's no dream but a real possibility hard as iron.

From youth we are told of something greater than ourselves. Something vast and unknowable that stretches beyond the boundaries of what mind can hold. They shepherd the young ones to wooden buildings with crosses hung like dead things on the walls or to temples where old men in robes speak ancient words. Some take what their mothers and fathers gave them and hold it close like a blanket against the dark while others cast it away saying there aint nothing out there but what we know and what we see. And we take up these beliefs like weapons only to lay them down again for different ones when the first ones fail us. Each soul walking its own path through the spiritual dark searching for some light to lead it home.

The old man said cardinal and nothing more. We set there on the porch listening to the rain hammer the tin roof while smoke from our cigarettes rose up in pale wisps to join the clouds. Water poured from the gutters and drowned the flowers that grew there, petals beaten flat against the mud. He looked out into the gray distance with eyes that seemed to see both now and then at once. His clothes hung on him like a scarecrow's and his head showed pale through thinning hair. He wouldnt look at me. I knew I could not speak of what was coming for speaking makes real what we wish was not. I moved closer and hugged him and we sat there watching the June rain fall in the growing dark.

He died in December. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The doctors with their medicines and machines had kept him breathing past their predictions but what good was breath when it only meant more pain. What sort of god would craft such torment. In the nighttime I spoke no prayers for if there was a god he had turned his face from me long ago.

I would not watch him die. Could not. The life that gave me life deserved better than my witness to its ending. I knew him better than they did. Better than the blood kin that gathered round his bed. He would not want his child to watch death take him. So I lay curled in my bed for three days waiting for word.

None came.

He walked the fields of Caroline county and knew the soil like his own blood. John Taylor. Man of the earth and of words both. The land spoke to him in ways that politics never could though he served in that capacity too and the marriage of these things made him what he was. A voice crying out against the wilderness of government overreach. Against the darkness that men brought forth when they strayed from honest work.

The republic stood newborn on the continent like some vast experiment in human nature. No ancient ghosts to bind it. No old world chains to wear. Taylor saw in this emptiness a terrible possibility. The chance to build something true. He knew that rights given by God or nature or whatever power ruled the hearts of men were like bones in a skeleton. Break one and the whole thing goes wrong. Goes twisted. These things must stay beyond the reach of any government that would call itself just.

In the raw state of nature the strong preyed upon the weak and the clever preyed upon both but Taylor believed civilization must rise above such base instincts. Must find a way to account for the light and dark that dwelled in every human heart. Good and evil. No middle ground between them. He wrote that government carried all the virtues and vices of the men who wielded it, like a sword that could heal or harm depending on whose hand held the hilt.

The principles he called good were simple things. Protection of what a man owned. The enhancement of agriculture. The restraint of those who would profit from paper and promises rather than honest work. Self-interest drove all men, he knew, but like fire it could warm a home or burn it down. Government must contain this force, must channel it, must be watched always lest it turn from servant to master.

He stood with others who read the Constitution like scripture, demanding every word be weighed and measured. The federal government must be bound tight, he said, kept small, kept lean, kept honest. A bloated government would turn tyrant as surely as meat turns rotten in summer heat. But words alone were not enough. The spirit of the law must be known, must be held sacred. The Declaration that came before was truer still, he thought. It spoke of sovereign states, not one nation. Separate fires burning bright against the dark.

He stood and looked down and the looking was a thing without meaning or purpose save that it was done. The mind worked at it like some machine spinning in emptiness, taking in what lay before it and letting go again without holding to any truth or knowing. Thoughts came and went like smoke in a wind. No thought stayed.

He'd bought him a book once. Some woman artist had told him of it. About drawing and the mind and how these things worked together or didnt work together and how a man might learn to see what was before him truly and not just what his mind told him ought to be there. The book spoke of frames. How putting a frame around a thing made it something else entirely. How a kitchen full of things became just a bowl of fruit on a table if you framed it right.

Standing there he couldnt frame nothing. The sight was too big for frames. Like them painters of old had their colors. Blues and greens and all the colors of God's earth. If he was to paint this scene it would be brown. Nothing but brown.

His fingers found the handle. Touched it. The muscles worked beneath the skin like creatures with their own purpose. Water moved in its ancient circles. Clear as light itself. Things broke apart in it and vanished. He worked the handle again. Faster now. Urgent. The brown mass stayed fixed like something alive and willful. Like it had made up its mind to stay.

He stood there in his tie that choked at his throat. Green like poison. Feet planted like a man about to receive news of death. The mop loose in his grip like a broken standard. Some previous visitor had left this offering. This message to them that cleaned the drugstore toilets. He flushed again and again and watched the water move and settle and move again. Then his hand went to the paper. Wrapping and wrapping until the hand was white as bone. He bent at the waist like a man in prayer. The hand went down into the water like something seeking baptism in darkness...

They die on the roads these children. Die in twisted metal and shattered glass while the night wraps around them like a shroud. The government men in their white coats say the young brain aint ready for such things but they dont need to tell what any fool can see with his own eyes. Inexperience sits heavy in their bones and death rides shotgun in their fathers pickup trucks.

The children gather like crows. Two then three then four in a car and the metal beast beneath them growls with promise and threat both. Studies done in California show what we already know in our hearts - that death multiplies with each young soul added to the cabin. Some states try to hold back the tide with their paper laws and provisional permits but its like trying to dam a river with chicken wire.

Zuckerman the headshrinker says eighteen years aint enough. Says the young ones seek the thrill of speed like junkies seek the needle and they cant help themselves no more than a rattler can help its poison. The boomers babies are coming he says. Coming like a flood to wash our roads in blood and metal and grief.

The answer lies simple as a coffin nail. Keep them from the wheel till eighteen years have worked their tempering. Let them learn in classrooms and parking lots with teachers watching careful as priests. Make it the same in every state so there aint no place for death to slip through the cracks. Six hours behind the wheel and fifty with a grown soul watching. Numbers writ in law like commandments.

This aint new thinking. But then neither is death and we seem to keep finding ways to deal in that particular trade.

They called it CAPD and it was a thing that lived in the brain and made the sounds wrong. Not in the hearing but in the knowing of what was heard. Like a radio playing through broken glass. The brain took the sounds and twisted them and made them strange and foreign though the ears worked just fine.

The disorder first showed itself in the middle years of the last century. Italian men with clinical minds sought to understand it. They worked in sterile rooms with machines and wires and children who could not parse the world of sound around them. Kimura came later with his tests of competing sounds fed into separate ears like twin serpents of noise coiling into the skull.

The affliction manifested in ways various and cruel. Some could not tell where sounds came from in the void of space as if they walked in darkness eternal. Others could not separate one sound from another or know when words meant their opposite through the tone of voice that carried them. The sounds came like waves breaking upon rocks, each one washing away the memory of the last until nothing remained but confusion.

To diagnose it they brought forth an arsenal of tests and observations like ancient priests seeking auguries in the behavior of their subjects. Audiologists and speech pathologists and psychologists all brought their tools to bear, watching and measuring and recording. They fed sounds into ears and measured the echoes that returned. But no single test could catch this ghost in the machine of the mind, and none could say from whence it came. It remained elusive as smoke, real as rain, present as pain.

They would sit children in rooms and bombard them with sounds, asking them to pluck meaning from chaos. Numbers and words would rain down like hail, and they would watch as the children struggled to catch them, to hold them, to make sense of the storm. Some could and some could not and in this way they separated the afflicted from the whole.

They'd asked what I aimed to do and I told them plain. Work with the children. The broken ones. The ones cast off and forgotten like old shoes in a ditch. Them that's been touched by darkness that walks in daylight wearing the skin of kin. Values aint just words wrote down in some book. They're carved deep in the bone. Service. Respect. The old ways of right and wrong that dont bend nor break.

I'd wandered some years not knowing my path. Watched folks run from their demons or drown em in whatever poison they could find. Got myself some learning in the ways of the mind at Piedmont College in 09 but still the path weren't clear. Then come a summer day I'll not forget. Boy of sixteen set on my friend's couch like a sparrow ready to fly. Eyes darting. Hands working at nothing. Running from them that should've protected him but didn't.

Next day I drove out to where he come from. Talked to the law standing in that yard where evil had made its home. Told em what I knew from my schooling. They asked me to speak to the parents and I did. Watched em squirm and lie, calling their boy's cry for help manipulation. Simple disputes, they said. Nothing simple about it. That's when I knew what I had to do.

Justice aint just a word neither. Society talks about the worth of one soul while trying to make every soul look the same. I never did hold with that. Through them school years I made my stand. Wore my colors like war paint. Put metal in my flesh where I pleased. Stood with them that society said weren't worth standing with. Fought the old poisons of hate and fear wherever they showed their face. Some folks say protest aint proper. I say there aint nothing more proper than standing against what's wrong.

That's the truth of it. Plain as I can tell it.

The night comes and with it the darkness that some cannot escape into sleep. There are those who walk among us bearing the curse of wakefulness, their minds racing like wild horses across the vast plains of consciousness while others find peace in the void. They call it insomnia but names mean little to those who suffer its relentless grip.

The men of science speak of two paths to understanding this affliction. One path leads through blood and bone, through the twisted helixes of our making that we inherit from those who came before. The other winds through the territories of man's own making - the streets and alleys of culture, the borderlands of race and wealth, the dark canyons between rich and poor.

In the laboratories they keep their mice in plastic boxes, watching as the creatures struggle between wake and sleep. The scientists speak of things called GABAB receptors, tiny gatekeepers in the hypothalamus that stand watch over the kingdom of sleep. They inject their potions - baclofen they call it - and observe as the mice surrender to unconsciousness. As if mice could tell us the secrets of human suffering.

They mapped these territories of sleep like ancient cartographers, drawing borders between what they call Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, primary disorders and secondary ones. Names upon names, categories within categories, as if naming a thing could capture its essence. Nightmare Disorder. Sleep Terror. Sleepwalking. Words that try to cage the uncageable.

In the end it all comes down to the firing of neurons in the dark meat of our brains, the dance of chemicals across synaptic gaps, the inheritance of cursed genes passed down like dark heirlooms through generations. And those who cannot sleep walk among us like ghosts, haunting fluorescent-lit offices and sterile classrooms, their eyes heavy with the weight of endless days.

Two and a half years I've walked these grounds. Four and a half seasons come and gone like wind across the valley. The campus stretches vast and merciless, a concrete expanse that swallows souls and time alike. In my first year they put me in East Halls, far out where the morning sun first touches university soil, beyond where most students dare venture save for football and spectacle.

The path from Stuart Hall to Willard was a pilgrimage. Twenty-five minutes through rain or snow or whatever god saw fit to cast down upon us. The old ones speak of times when East stood alone, islands of brick and mortar in seas of empty land. Now steel and glass rise where emptiness once dwelled. The Creamery. The healing house. Apartments like teeth in a giant's mouth surrounding it all. The campus grows like some living thing, consuming space, making distance longer with each passing season.

What salvation exists for those who must traverse these spaces? The bicycle stands alone. Simple machine. Two wheels and frame and chain. But it aint enough to have the machine. You need the riders and you need the paths that welcome them.

I knew a man who returned to the wheel after years away. Said he couldn't reckon why he ever stopped. Called it the only true way to move through this world. A bowl of morning grain can power you thirty miles or more, he said, and I reckon he spoke true.

I live off campus now, far as any dormitory, maybe farther. The bike was wisdom purchased cheap. Thomas building lies twenty-five minutes by foot from my door, but the wheels cut it to five if you're willing to push. Pollock Road runs straight as an arrow but aint always friendly to those who'd ride it. Walking has its merits but time is precious as blood in this place. Without the bike I'd lose thirty minutes, forty maybe, each day to walking. Two and a half hours every week vanished like morning mist. Add the other wanderings required of a student's life and time becomes a currency you cant afford to spend.

He saw the machines coming and knew their masters well. The World Controllers and their ilk. They had built their glass towers and concrete hives where men moved like insects, each to their own predetermined place in the great mechanism of society. The conditioning began at birth, perhaps before. No man could say. They called it community but it was a prison of the soul.

The people walked through their lives like sleepwalkers, pursuing pleasure with the mindless determination of addicts. They knew nothing of struggle or pain or the raw truth of existence. The Controller stood above them all like some dark god, dispensing soma and satisfaction in measured doses. Marx had seen it coming. The way the powerful would bend the minds of the weak until they could no longer recognize their own chains.

There was no love in this brave new world. No hatred neither. Just the endless cycle of consumption and shallow gratification. The men spoke of women like they spoke of machines, measuring their worth in pneumatic qualities and physical dimensions. The women traded stories of their couplings with the detached interest of cattle traders. Each class moved in its ordained circles, never questioning, never rising above their station. The Alphas and Betas, those who might have seen the truth of things, chose blindness instead. All except Bernard, who carried his doubt like a wound.

The lower orders - Deltas, Gammas, the rest - they were born to their servitude, their minds shaped before they drew first breath. Sleep-teaching had burned away any chance of rebellion or discontent. They consumed and labored and died, believing themselves blessed in their ignorance. The great machinery of capitalism ground on, feeding on their dreams, their desires, their very humanity. And above it all the Controller watched, counting his profits in the coin of human souls.

Four years past I sat in a classroom where they spoke of Islam, voices rising and falling like wind through desert scrub. The question hung there like smoke: was this faith born of violence. Now in these days the question burns hotter still, a flame that won't die down. Since the towers fell I watched how the papers and talking heads shifted from raw hatred to something else, something like submission. Strange days indeed when a man called Barack Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his veins, could reach for the highest office in this land.

The Prophet's tale gnaws at me. What they write of Muhammad stands against what history whispers in the dark corners of time. They say he was a peaceful man but I know different. Know how he rode with warriors across the sands, how tribes fell before him like wheat before the scythe, how the sword and the word went hand in hand. Yet in these pages they paint him gentle as a lamb, a martyr walking soft in the world until men saw truth in his eyes and followed. Followed like sheep to water.

And there in those pages they write of miracles. Mutton and milk multiplied like some dark echo of another story, older and truer. As if taking the bread and fish from Christ's own hands and putting them in another's. A theft of holy things. Making mockery of sacred blood.

They tell these tales second-hand, third-hand, passed down like old coins worn smooth with handling. Each teller adding his own truth until truth itself becomes suspect. Like smoke rising from a fire you cannot see.

What troubles me most is how they've made him soft, this warrior prophet. Made him meek and mild when history shows his sword arm was strong and his will was iron.
